instruction: What kind of spectrum was used to discriminate between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH)?
Output: Near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy was used to discriminate between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH).

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to discriminate between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH)?
Output: Standard normal variate (SNV) preprocessing and Relief algorithm for feature selection were used to discriminate between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH).

instruction: What metric was chosen to discriminate between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH) and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the diagnostic model in the related study is accuracy. The accuracy of the model is reported to be 95.2% on the independent test sets.

instruction: What machine learning model was proposed in the related study to construct the diagnostic model for discriminating between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH) using near-infrared (NIR spectroscopy) and chemometrics?
Output: The machine learning model proposed in the related study to construct the diagnostic model for discriminating between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with ONFH using NIR spectroscopy and chemometrics is the ensemble-based extreme learning machines modeling method (EELM).

instruction: Can the proposed EELM algorithm combined with NIR spectroscopy be considered superior to traditional methods in discriminating between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with ONFH?
Output: Yes, the proposed EELM algorithm combined with NIR spectroscopy can be considered superior to traditional methods in discriminating between normal and osteonecrosis tissues in patients with ONFH. The results of the related study showed that the EELM algorithm achieved a total accuracy of 95.2% on independent test sets, while the traditional method (PLS-DA) only achieved 78.5% accuracy. This indicates that the EELM algorithm provides a more accurate and reliable diagnostic model for discriminating ONFH tissues from normal ones. Therefore, the combination of NIR spectroscopy and the EELM algorithm can be considered a potential tool for this purpose, surpassing the traditional methods.
